answer: You didn't do anything about it out of respect for the fact that she wouldn't let you near her with a ten foot pole, which is, by the way, about nine feet, nine inches off the mark anyway.

question: That's true. Oh, God, Lotte, what have I become? My wife in a cage with a monkey. A gun in my hand. Betrayal in my heart.
answer: Maybe this is what you've always been, Craig, you just never faced it before.

question: Perhaps you're right. I can't let you go though. Too much has happened. You're my ace in the hole.
answer: I need a shower.

question: I'm sorry. Oh God, I'm sorry. I'm some kind of monster. I'm the guy you read about in the paper and go, "he's some kind of monster."
answer: You're not a monster, Craig. Just a confused man.

question: Oh, Elijah, you are magnificent! Maxine! Listen
answer: Really? Well, you know, he's quite good. I'm surprised. Anyway, I have a session with Malkovich I have to attend. I'll speak with you soon.

question: But Maxine, I thought it was me you loved.
answer: I thought so too, doll. I guess we were mistaken.

question: Come on in.
answer: I can explain about the portal, darling.

question: Don't con me, Maxine. We're over. I just let you up here to tell you that, and to tell you that I'm taking you and Schwartz to court.
answer: Oh shut up. Craig, darling are you in there?

question: Yes. How did you know it was me?
answer: Lotte called me.

question: Oh, so the bitch escaped.
answer: Apparently you can control this Malkovich fellow now.

question: I'm getting better all the time.
answer: I'll say you are. Let's do it on his kitchen table, then make him eat an omelette off of it.

question: You know I think it pays to leave juice-making to the trained professionals. You look terrible, my dear.
answer: Craig stole Maxine from me, Dr. Lester.

question: Hmmm, a lesbian, are you? I must inform you that I find that highly arousing.
answer: No, you don't understand. I've been inside Malkovich when I'm with Maxine...

question: What?! That is not allowed. My God, you are supposed to be one of us. You know you must never partake of Malkovich by yourself!
answer: No, I didn't know that.

question: Oh, didn't anyone show you the indoctrination video?
answer: No.

question: Oh, sorry. Right this way.
answer: Does Floris know that she's the chosen?

question: You still there, sweets?
answer: Yeah. I've figured out how to hold on as long as I want. Oddly enough, it's all in the wrists.

question: Wow. Do a puppet show for me, Craig honey.
answer: You mean with Malkovich?

question: I'd love to see your work.
answer: Really? Yeah. Okay. I'll do something I call "Craig's Dance of Despair and Disillusionment."

question: That was incredible. You're brilliant!
answer: You see, Maxine, it isn't just playing with dolls.

question: You're right, my darling, it's so much more. It's playing with people! Stay in him forever?
answer: No! But how will we make a living, my love, if our clientele doesn't have access to our product?

question: Well, we'll have all the money in Malkovich's bank account, plus he still gets acting work occasionally.
answer: No! Please! Shut up, will you? We're trying to think here. It is sort of like being a puppeteer. I like that about it.

question: No one would ever have to know its not him.
answer: Wait a minute! What if everybody knew? What if we presented Malkovich as the world's most complicated puppet and me as the only puppeteer sophisticated enough to work him? We'd wipe the floor with the Great Mantini!

question: Aaaahhhh, the portal!
answer: You bastard!

question: No! Don't harm the vessel!
answer: It's Craig in there, I can tell.

question: Teresa, get me a chicken soup. Chicken soup?
answer: I'll get right to the point, Larry. I'm a puppet now...

question: Okay.
answer: I'm being controlled by the world's greatest puppeteer, Craig Schwartz...

question: Oh yeah, he's good.
answer: ... and I want to show off his skills by performing a one-puppet extravaganza in Reno.

question: Well, let's see what we've got here. My God, where am I? This seems so familiar. My God, I'm Hitler in the bunker! Aaaahhhh! Aaaah! Oh, I'm just the actor in that Twilight Zone episode. Thank you all for your efforts, but I'm afraid we can no longer get into Malkovich through the portal.
answer: Why not? I need to get in there!

question: I'm not certain, my dear, but I believe your husband has somehow psychically diverted the route.
answer: That bastard! I'll gladly dispose of him in the name of the order, Son of Malkovich.

question: Lots of carrot juice, little lady. That, and a deal with the Devil. Surprise. Wait! It's not that bad! When we get into Malkovich, we still get to rule the world, just like I told you. The only difference is that we rule in the name of evil, instead of good. Absolutely. So anyway...
answer: Well, I for one, am resigning. I will not serve evil. I am ashamed of all of you.

question: My dear, let me assure you that when we attain power, it will be much more pleasant for those inside Malkovich, than for those outside.
answer: I'll take my chances.

question: Anybody else?
answer: Do we get to wear a crown?

question: But of course.
answer: Count me in.

question: Good. I think its time to beckon Mr. Flemmer. Perhaps He can help us out of this pickle.
answer: Boy, this is a toughie. To be honest, I didn't anticipate this.

question: And as I said, sir, we can't very well exert physical persuasion upon the sacred vessel Malkovich.
answer: Right, Lester. I heard you the first time. I'm not a dummy.

question: Didn't mean to imply that you were, sir.
answer: Look, I'm going back to my house to ponder this. So stay calm and keep track of Schwartz's comings and goings. Oh, and somebody dispose of Schwartz's wife, will you? Nice to meet you all.

question: It's open.
answer: It's just me, boss. I brought croissants.

question: Have a seat. I wracking my brain over this Malkovich thing.
answer: We saw his show at the Luxor last night.

question: Vegas? What'd you think?
answer: The kid's got talent. You've never seen Malkovich like this. Schwartz had him up there singing and dancing. Impressions.

question: Impressions? Those are hard.
answer: Very talented son of a bitch. Too bad we can't kill him.

question: I suppose I could come to him in a dream. I don't know. That's the best I can think of right now.
answer: A scary dream?

question: No, a sexy dream. Of course, a scary dream.
answer: I like that.

question: Who are you?
answer: I am the Devil.

question: Oh.
answer: Leave Malkovich. He is mine.

question: Bad dream, darling?
answer: I've got to leave Malkovich.

question: You've got to be kidding.
answer: I just had the most horrifying nightmare. The devil was in it.

question: Derek Mantini!
answer: Hello, Schwartz. I saw your show.

question: Did you see the reviews?
answer: Yeah, I saw them

question: I won't waste your time Schwartz, or more importantly, mine. Here's my proposal
answer: How do we do that?

question: A friendly competition, if you will. Your Malkovich puppet and my Harry S. Truman puppet appear opposite each other in a play. Not some Vegas Burly-Q pyrotechnics, but a real play that requires actual acting. The audience decides who is more deserving of the title. The losing puppeteer bows out graciously. Goes back to obscurity as a file clerk.
answer: What's the play?

question: Say... "Equus"? It's got everything.
answer: Never heard of it.

question: Broadway's finest three hours. It's about the suppression of the individual. Conformity as God in modern society.
answer: Sounds boring. Are there any songs?

question: Nothing but acting to hide behind, buddy-boy.
answer: I'm not afraid. I toured for a year with the National Puppet Company's production of "Long Day's Journey Into Night."

question: Great then.
answer: Is there dancing?

question: No.
answer: Who needs dancing?

question: How'd it go? Did you say the philodendron gets water or no?
answer: No, for God's sake, I just watered it yesterday. It almost went well. I gave a pretty good dream, but circumstances arose.

question: What kind of circumstances?
answer: Maxine says she'll leave him if he leaves Malkovich, plus he's been challenged to a puppet-duel by Mantini.

question: The Great Mantini?
answer: No, the Mediocre Mantini. Of course the Great Mantini!

question: Oh, he's good! Great, actually. I saw him do "Tru" with his sixty foot Robert Morse puppet. Sensational.
answer: But I think I have another plan.

question: Do tell. I love a good plan.
answer: Why are you being like this?

question: I missed you. I'm sorry. Tell me the plan.
answer: Well, if Mantini wins, Schwartz will leave Malkovich, right? So, if he needs it, I help Mantini's performance a bit, give him an edge. Spice up the show.

question: Can you do that? I mean, do you know anything about puppetry?
answer: I am the Devil, Lester. I think I can handle it.

question: I was just asking. No disrespect intended.
answer: Fine. Let's drop it.

question: Fine. I mean, it's not like I was doubting you, it's just that I know puppetry is a skill that takes a long time to acquire.
answer: Fine. I'm not mad. Let's just drop it.

question: Do you dream often?
answer: Do you?

question: It's my job to ask the questions. Yours to answer them.
answer: Says who?

question: Says me. Do you dream often?
answer: Do you?

question: Must you take this terrible demon on yourself, my love?
answer: Yes. I'm the only one. I have to enter Malkovich and destroy him from the inside. If not me, who?

question: If there was any way I could go in your place. But I'm only a monkey and...
answer: Hush, sweetheart. I'll be with you always, my friends. Who knows, maybe if I'm lucky, I'll rejoin you with wings and a beak.

question: Wings and a halo, my darling. Wings and a halo.
answer: My God!

question: My God!
answer: I'm so glad you're safe. You look really wonderful.

question: I'm in love. For the first time. It's funny, but when it happens to you, there's no question.
answer: He's a lucky man. Do I know him?

question: It's Elijah.
answer: The iguana?

question: The monkey.
answer: Oh, right. As long as you're happy. I'm sure he's a better lover than I ever was.

question: A better friend.
answer: I'm sorry for everything.

question: It's okay, Craig. It all worked out, in an odd sort of way.
answer: You came up here looking for the portal?

question: Yeah. I was going to kill him from the inside.
answer: And yourself too in the process. God, you're so beautiful. Why couldn't I see that before?

question: You saw it once. Now you see it again. That's life, isn't it? And you were up here to try the same thing, weren't you?
answer: I suppose. But they got here first, the lousy bastards. So now it's all over, I guess.

question: I don't know. There's a small community of us. We have a place they don't know about. We're happy. We'll keep trying to figure out a way. Come stay with us. Join the struggle.
answer: You'll have me, after all I've done to you?

question: People make mistakes.
answer: I'm through with puppets, Lotte. I just want you to know that.

question: I know.
answer: I'd like to be a farmer. I want to help things grow, to encourage life. Do you and your friends need a farmer?

question: Sure. We could really use a farmer. We'd be grateful for the help. Also, I think, you know, if you wouldn't mind too terribly, a little puppet show every once in a while, would do a lot to lift our spirits. You know, if you wouldn't mind too terribly. Oh honey. It's gonna be okay.
answer: I love you, Lotte.
